meanings.def: a barrier like a door that is used to close an opening in a fence or a wall outside a building
examples: the front/main gate
the back/side gate
an iron gate
to open/close/shut a gate
He pushed open the garden gate.
outside a gate Students were still standing outside the school gates.
at a gate A crowd gathered at the factory gates.
gate to something Someone was waiting by the gate to his house.
Don't forget to shut the gate when you leave.
The gate shut behind him.
The great gates of the abbey were shut fast.
The heavy gate swung open.
a set of ornamental gates
a wide driveway with double gates

meanings.def: an opening that can be closed by a gate or gates
examples: I was slightly nervous as I entered the gates.
through a gate We drove through the palace gates.
Go through the gate and continue down the track.
He led us through a gate into a little garden.
Hesitantly, he emerged from the gates of the prison.

meanings.def: a way out of an airport through which passengers go to get on their plane
examples: Passengers for Paris should proceed to gate 8.
at a gate BA flight 726 to Paris is now boarding at gate 16.

meanings.def: a barrier that is used to control the flow of water on a river or canal
examples: a lock/sluice gate

meanings.def: the number of people who attend a sports event
examples: Tonight's game has attracted the largest gate of the season.

meanings.def: the amount of money made by selling tickets for a sports event
examples: Today's gate will be given to charity.

meanings.def: a political scandal connected with the person or place mentioned
an electronic switch that reacts in one of two ways to data that is put into it. A computer performs operations by passing data through a very large number of gates.
to be successful from the beginning, especially in sport
examples: The Grizzlies came out of the gate motivated, bursting to a 27–10 lead.
The team has struggled to get out of the gate this year.

meanings.def: right from the beginning of a situation or an activity
examples: The trouble began right out of the gate.
The Democrats had a clear advantage out of the gate.

idioms.idiom: come, get, etc. out of the gate(s)
idioms.def: to be successful from the beginning, especially in sport
examples: The Grizzlies came out of the gate motivated, bursting to a 27–10 lead.
The team has struggled to get out of the gate this year.

idioms.def: right from the beginning of a situation or an activity
examples: The trouble began right out of the gate.
The Democrats had a clear advantage out of the gate.
